Rationale  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is supporting the Philippine 
Government's plans to restructure and privatize the electric power 
industry,  and  create  a  competitive  wholesale  electricity  spot 
market  (WESM).  Important  requirements  of  a  competitive 
electricity  market  include  a  functional  wholesale  market 
management system and adequate transmission capacity. With 
the implementation of a WESM, competition in the power sector 
will bring electricity prices closer to marginal cost in the medium 
and long term. All of the transmission components included in the 
proposed  Project  are  also  of  high-priority  for  the  National 
Transmission Corporation (TRANSCO) as defined in its least-cost 
transmission  development  plan.  In  particular,  the  substation 
expansion will enable completion of rural electrification programs 
in Mindanao, one of the poorest regions in the Philippines. The 
Project  fits  into  ADB's  country  operational  strategy  for  the 
Philippines. 
   
Objective and Scope  The Project will support the Government’s objective to improve 
the  accessibility,  quality,  affordability,  and  sustainability  of  the 
national electricity supply by (i) facilitating the establishment of a 
spot  market  so  that  electricity  generation  is  dispatched  on  a 
competitive basis to meet the power demand at a lower cost, and 
(ii) reinforcing and upgrading the critical transmission lines and 
substations in Luzon and Mindanao to ensure a reliable power 
supply and provide capacity for rural electrification.  
   
Project Description  The Project consists of two parts. Part A includes procurement 
and installation of the WESM market management hardware, with 
software and system integration including consultancy services. 
Part B includes (i) upgrading the Luzon transmission grid [about 
80 kilometers (km) of 230 kilovolts (kV) double circuit transmission 
lines from San Manuel in Pangasinan Province to Concepcion in 
Tarlac Province and 37 km of double circuit transmission lines, 
from Concepcion to Mexico in Pampanga Province and substation 
expansions],  and  (ii)  expanding  the  Mindanao  substation 
(procurement  and  installation  of  additional  power  transformers 
and power circuit breakers at the Bislig, Butuan, Davao, Kibawe, 
Sta. Clara, and Tindalo substations).

Project Benefits and  With the introduction of WESM, generation will be dispatched on 
Beneficiaries  the  basis  of  prices  bid  into  the  market,  with  the  lowest  price 
generator being dispatched first.  In this way, for each trading 
period, the price of electricity bought and sold on the wholesale 
market will be set by the electricity demand and the prices bid by 
competing generators to supply energy into the market.  Initially, 
given the surplus of generation connected to the grid, wholesale 
electricity  prices  are  expected  to  decline.    Over  time,  as  the 
surplus generation is absorbed, prices can be expected to rise 
closer  to  the  long  run  marginal  cost  of  electricity  generation, 
providing economic signals to encourage efficient investment in 
new generation. 
 
Upgrading  the  Luzon  transmission  line  capacities  will  enable 
power from plants in northern Luzon to be transmitted efficiently 
and reliably to the main load centers in and around Metro Manila. 
Expansion  of  the  Mindanao  substations  will  increase  the 
substation  capacities,  thereby  assuring  efficient  and  reliable 
delivery of power to customers in rural areas in particular.  
 
   
Risks and Assumptions  Some  risks  are  associated  with  the  proposed  Project,  and 
measures are included to minimize their occurrence and effect. 
The design of the WESM in the Philippines has taken into account 
the lessons learned in developing electricity markets in other parts 
of the world. The technical risks associated with the proposed 
transmission  development  components  are  considered 
manageable because the design and construction are based on 
conventional and proven technologies.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the National Power Corporation (NPC), to be guaranteed by the Republic of the Philippines 
(the  Government),  for  the  Electricity  Market  and  Transmission  Development  Project  (the 
Project).  The  report  also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  assist  the 
Government in the transition to competitive electricity market, and if the Board approves the 
proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has had a long involvement in, and is highly 
supportive of, the Government's plans to restructure and privatize the electric power industry, 
and create a competitive electricity market. Such restructuring is in conformity with ADB's 
Energy Policy,1 and is a vehicle to help overcome many of the current problems of the sector. 
The appraisal mission2 was fielded during 22 July to 9 August 2002 to determine the scope of 
the  Project  on  the  basis  of  the  preparatory  work  of  the  earlier  proposed  transmission 
interconnection and reinforcement project (TIRP).3  Three components of the TIRP are now 
included in the proposed Project because their implementation cannot be deferred further as 
they are critical to avoid disruptions in the transmission system and  for the creation of a 
competitive market. In line with the Government’s least-cost transmission development plan, the 
Project will also enable implementation of accelerated rural electrification programs, particularly 
in Mindanao, one of the poorest regions in the Philippines. The Project fits into ADB's country 
operational strategy for the Philippines. The project framework is attached as Appendix 1 and 
the chronology of project processing is in Appendix 2. 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Energy Sector 
3.  Being highly dependent on imported energy, the Philippines has to contend with price 
fluctuations  in  international  energy  markets.  As  such,  exploration  for  and  development  of 
indigenous energy resources to enhance self-sufficiency has been a continuing thrust of the 
Government since the oil crisis of the 1970s. In addition to the increasing use of indigenous 
coal, oil, geothermal, and hydro resources, the development of the Malampaya gas field and the 
successful commissioning of natural-gas fired power stations in 2002 has significantly increased 
the country’s energy self-sufficiency ratio to more than 50% from 44% in 2001. Increased 
emphasis has recently been given to the use of new and renewable energy resources such as 
wind, solar, and mini-hydro, which are expected to be increasingly used to generate electricity in 
remote areas.

2.  Electricity Subsector 
5.  Prior to the ongoing power sector’s restructuring, power generation functions in the 
Philippines were shared between the NPC and several independent power producers (IPPs) 
with  contracts  to  sell  electricity  to  NPC  and  Manila  Electric  Company  (MERALCO).  The 
transmission functions were carried out by NPC. Distribution was carried out by MERALCO, 16 
privately owned utilities, 7 municipal systems, and 119 member-owned electric cooperatives 
that manage retail sales mostly in rural areas. NPC was also engaged in the direct sale of bulk 
electricity to large industrial customers.  
 
6.  The total installed generating capacity at the end of 2001, excluding the small island 
grids, amounted to 13,459 megawatts (MW) consisting of 71% in Luzon, 14% in the Visayas, 
and 15% in Mindanao. The generation mix comprised 19% hydropower, 14% geothermal, 28% 
coal-based thermal, and 39% oil-based thermal plants.   
 
7.  As of December 2001, the transmission system had a substation capacity of 22,390 
megavolt amperes (MVA), of which 83% is in Luzon, 10% in the Visayas, and 7% in Mindanao. 
Its transmission lines of various voltages extend up to 30,373 circuit-kilometers (km), of which 
66% is in Luzon, 15% in the Visayas, and 19% in Mindanao.  
 
8.  As  part  of  the  PEP,  the  Power  Development  Plan  (PDP)  and  the  Transmission 
Development Plan (TDP) are prepared by DOE on the basis of the power demand projections. 
As the current surplus generating capacity will be gradually absorbed by the growing demand 
around 2005, the PDP provides for a net capacity addition of about 11,600 MW up to 2011. 
Accordingly, the TDP envisages an addition of 11,376 km of transmission and subtransmission 
lines and 22,450 MVA of substation capacity. Aside from the new transmission projects, the 
TDP also incorporates rehabilitation and upgrading works to ensure the reliability of the existing 
networks.  
 
  3.  Poverty Issues and the Sector 
 
9.  Inadequate basic infrastructure, including roads and electricity facilities, has limited the 
development of rural areas. By the end of 2001, electrification at village level was 82%, leaving 
about 7,000 villages unelectrified. About 80% of the households in unelectrified villages are 
below the poverty threshold level of annual income of P55,470 (in 2000 prices) or $1,073. 
Access to electricity is uneven; close to half the households in the lowest 40% income group 
lack access to electricity as compared to 9 out of 10 households in the highest 60% income 
group having access. In Mindanao, even the non-poor have a relatively low level of coverage 
indicating that access rather than affordability is the issue.

3 
10.  The  Government  has  an  accelerated  rural  electrification  program  that  targets  the 
electrification of all villages by 2006. Parallel with electrification efforts, the Government aims to 
reduce poverty in the areas to be electrified by promoting income-generating activities that may 
be introduced following electrification. The cost of rural electrification is relatively high due to the 
predominantly residential customer profile, low per capita electricity consumption, and high 
system  losses.  For  this  reason,  a  number  of  provisions  have  been  made  to  benefit  rural 
customers. One such provision is the village electrification fund established by Republic Act 
7638 of 1998 from levies from power generation facilities. The fund partly finances village 
electrification in communities hosting these facilities.  
 
4.  External Assistance to the Sector 
11.  ADB is the lead official development partner in the energy sector, with a focus on the 
electricity subsector. Since 1971, ADB has provided 24 loans with a combined amount of 
$2.258  billion  to  help  develop  the  Philippine  energy  sector,  including  19  loans  to  NPC, 
guaranteed by the Republic of the Philippines, with a combined value of $1.557 billion. In 
addition to its lending, ADB has given 29 technical assistance (TA) grants to the energy sector 
totaling $10.7 million covering areas such as coal industry development, rural electrification, 
energy  conservation,  tariff  and  pricing  studies,  regulation,  consumer  impact  assessment, 
geothermal steam and  natural gas pricing studies, power development planning, feasibility 
studies, and environmental assessments. A list of ADB assistance to the energy sector is in 
Appendix 3. 
 
12.  Other major multilateral and bilateral agencies involved in the sector include the World 
Bank, Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC), Export-Import Bank of the United States 
(US), US Agency for International Development (USAid), US Trade and Development Agency, 
Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau (KfW), Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC)

5.  Lessons Learned 
13.  Of the 19 ADB loans to NPC, 18 projects have been physically completed and 8 of these

slow approval of contract awards. To reduce such delays, NPC standardized bidding documents

forecasting techniques for preparing its power development plan since 1995. NPC enhanced its

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Major Problems 
14.  In the early 1990s, Luzon experienced severe power shortages, leading to prolonged 
blackouts and adverse impacts on the economy. With the Government’s support, NPC and 
MERALCO contracted IPPs to resolve the power crisis. The East Asian financial crisis starting 
in 1997 suppressed economic growth and reduced electricity demand, leading to surplus power 
generating capacity. NPC’s debt service burden has spiraled upwards in recent years due to the 
lack  of  Government  equity  for  capital  expansion  programs,  NPC’s  heavy  reliance  on  debt 
finance,  and  the  major  depreciation  of  the  peso  against  foreign  currencies  in  NPC’s  debt 
portfolio.  Moreover,  the  IPP  contracts  included  high  cost  premiums  because  of  perceived 
investor risks. NPC, in some cases, paid fixed capacity charges to IPPs without availing of the 
electricity supply. Transmission bottlenecks, caused mainly by delays in obtaining the ROWs for 
construction of new lines, together with the excess capacity, have resulted in additional costs. In 
the distribution subsector, power losses are high, as 20 electricity cooperatives have system 
losses in the range of 16% to 20%, and another 24 electric cooperatives have system losses in 
excess of 20%. A combination of these factors has resulted in Philippine power rates being one 
of the highest among ADB’s developing member economies (Table 1).

2.  Power Sector Restructuring Program 
16.  The particular problems facing the power sector in the Philippines must be addressed if 
an accessible, high quality, affordable, and sustainable electricity supply is to be assured. The 
Government has therefore decided to restructure the electric power industry. This restructuring 
is similar to that undertaken in many other countries and will involve (i) disaggregation of the 
industry into generation, transmission, distribution, and supply, (ii) introduction of competition in 
the  generation  and  supply  sectors,  (iii)  introduction  of  a  wholesale  electricity  spot  market 
(WESM), (iv) privatization of generation and operation of transmission by a concessionaire, (v) 
introduction of open access to distribution networks, and (vi) regulation of the industry by a 
regulator independent of government.  
 
17.  Restructuring of the power sector has progressed along the lines established by the 
Electric Power Industry Reform Act (EPIRA) approved in June 2001. Under the EPIRA, Power 
Sector  Assets  and  Liabilities  Management  Corporation  (PSALM)  has  been  established  to 
manage  the  privatization,  TRANSCO  has  been  constituted  as  a  stand-alone  transmission 
organization,  and  the  independent  Electricity  Regulatory  Commission  (ERC)  has  been 
established.  Furthermore, NPC has been reorganized in preparation for privatization. A final 
draft of the WESM rules has been issued and the grid and distribution codes have been 
promulgated. The Joint Congressional Power Commission endorsed the PSALM’s privatization 
plan for NPC on 29 August 2002 and the President of the Philippines signed the privatization 
plan on 4 October 2002. According to the plan, a qualified private concessionaire will be 
selected in the first half of 2003 to operate TRANSCO’s transmission assets. The generation 
assets will be privatized through international competitive bidding in the second half of 2003.

3.  Project Rationale 
19.  By  2011  electricity  demand  is  forecast  to  increase  by  130%  above  current  levels.  
Consistent with the PEP, continuing reinforcement of the transmission grid is required to support 
this increased demand.  If such reinforcement does not occur, the quality and sustainability of 
the electricity supply will deteriorate and transmission losses will increase to uneconomic levels.  
The Project is consistent with this required capacity augmentation and, more particularly, with 
ADB’s policy objectives in supporting the development and restructuring of the Philippines’ 
electricity industry. 
 
20.  An important facet of power sector restructuring is the establishment of the WESM. The 
WESM will facilitate competition in electricity generation. Under the WESM, each day will be 
divided into 24 one-hour trading periods. Generation will be dispatched on the basis of prices 
bid into the market, with the lowest price generator being dispatched first. In this way, for each 
trading period, the price of electricity bought and sold on the wholesale market will be set by the 
electricity demand and the prices bid by competing generators to supply energy into the market.  
Initially, given the surplus of generation connected to the grid, wholesale electricity prices can 
be expected to decrease. Over time, as the surplus of generation is absorbed, prices can be 
expected to rise closer to the LRMC of electricity generation, providing economic signals to 
encourage efficient investment in new generation. 
 
21.  While PSALM has decided to establish a pilot market management system (MMS) in the 
first half of 2003 to undertake initial market operations and to train market participants, the 
Project will provide the permanent MMS hardware and software that is necessary to operate a 
fully functional WESM. This will be designed to allow for phased implementation so that it will 
initially support a market with limited functionality, which will not depend on the availability of all 
the planned systems needed to support fully automated market operation across all three 
TRANSCO grids. As enhancements to the transmission system are completed, the functionality 
of the MMS will be progressively improved. These enhancements are in progress and financed 
by the World Bank. A more detailed description of the WESM, and its relationship to other 
ongoing projects, is given in Appendix 4. 
 
22.  A competitive wholesale market will be more efficient if the transmission network has 
sufficient capacity to transport the power between the generators competing for dispatch and 
the load. If a transmission network is capacity constrained, cheaper generation may need to be 
replaced by more expensive plant located closer to the load. This will increase market prices 
and reduce the overall effectiveness of the market. The Project will increase the capacity of the 
transmission  network  by  strengthening  the  existing  230  kilovolt  (kV)  network  to  provide  a 
backup  transmission  corridor  between  the  generation  in  Northern  Luzon  and  Manila. 
Furthermore,  the  San  Manuel-Concepcion-Mexico  transmission  lines  that  will  be  upgraded 
under  the  Project  are  hazardous  since  they  no  longer  meet  minimum  ground  clearance 
requirements due to the impact of the Mt. Pinatubo eruption.  Based on TRANSCO’s load flow 
simulations, the San Manuel-Concepcion-Mexico transmission lines are sometimes overloaded 
even under normal operating conditions.  
 
23.  The acceleration of rural electrification, particularly in Mindanao, is another important 
policy objective. Mindanao contains about 24% of the country’s population, and 38% of its poor. 
Over 50% of the people in Mindanao are poor, compared to the national average of 34%. As 
many  as  62%  of  the  poor  in  Mindanao  have  no  access  to  electricity.  In  view  of  the 
Government’s plan for rural electrification and the scheduled commissioning of a new coal-fired 
power station in Mindanao, six major substations in Western, Eastern, Central, Northern and

7 
Southern Mindanao will be expanded to accommodate the increasing power load in their service 
areas. The substations to be upgraded have been chosen because their maximum electricity 
demands  are  approaching  the  substation  capacities.  The  expansion  of  the  substations  in 
Mindanao will provide additional capacity to support the Government’s objective of electrifying 
all villages by 2006. 
    
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objective 
24.  The  Project  will  provide  the  system  and  infrastructure  to  support  the  ongoing 
development of the power sector by (i) providing infrastructure to support the establishment of 
the WESM, which will allow the privatization of electricity generation companies to meet the 
power demand at a lower cost, and (ii) reinforcing and upgrading critical transmission lines and 
substations in Luzon and Mindanao, which will improve the reliability of the power supply, and 
help expand rural electrification.  
 
B.  Components and Outputs 
25.  The  Project  consists  of  two  parts.  Part  A  involves  implementation  of  the  market 
management system (MMS) for the WESM, and integration of the system into the wider WESM 
infrastructure, including consultancy services. Part B involves transmission reinforcement by 
upgrading the Luzon transmission lines and expanding the Mindanao substations. 
 
1.  Part A – Market Management System for WESM 
26.  This component will provide the computer hardware and software required to manage 
the bidding, dispatch optimization, and market settlement functions of the WESM. The hardware 
includes the main servers, application servers, meter data servers, data warehouses, electronic 
commerce servers, networking equipment, user interface work stations, and backup hardware. 
The software includes standard and customer-tailored components developed for the Philippine 
WESM, and backup software. Consulting services are required to (i) supervise the performance 
of  the  turnkey  contractor  with  regard  to  software  design  and  hardware  acquisition,  and 
functional  testing,  (ii)  perform  quality  control  functions,  (iii)  supervise  and  assist  in  the 
installation, system integration, and commissioning phases of the subproject, and (iv) provide 
necessary training. 
 
27.  The DOE will constitute an autonomous group market operator (AGMO), which will 
initially operate the market under the administrative supervision of TRANSCO. In accordance 
with Section 7 of the EPIRA, the AGMO will be replaced, within 1 year of market start, by an 
independent market operator (IMO) that is financially and technically capable, with proven 
experience, and with expertise of not less than 2 years as a leading IMO of similar or larger size 
electricity markets. ADB will assist the AGMO prepare for the operation of the WESM and 
support the Government in the selection of the IMO through grant-financed TA (paras. 61 and 
62). 
 
2.  Part B - Transmission Reinforcement  
28.  Luzon Transmission Upgrading. This component consists of procuring and installing 
lines  and  substation  equipment  to  reinforce  and  upgrade  the  existing  230  kV  overhead 
transmission network in Luzon to increase the transfer capacities to accommodate the load

8 
growth in the concerned provinces. The San Manuel-Concepcion (80 km) and Concepcion-
Mexico (37 km) lines will be upgraded from single circuit-single conductor to double circuit-twin 
conductor (Map 1).  Apart from having low current carrying capacity, these lines have been a 
safety hazard, with many parts of the line too close to the ground.  Furthermore, substations will 
be upgraded as necessary to support the increased capacity transmission lines. 
 
29.  Mindanao  Substation  Expansion.  This  component  consists  of  procurement  and 
installation of 6 units of 138/69 kV power transformers with a total capacity of 525 megavolt-
amperes (MVA), 9 units of 138 kV and 15 units of 69 kV power circuit breakers at Bislig, Butuan, 
Davao, Kibawe, Sta. Clara and Tindalo (Map 2).  This will accommodate increasing electricity 
demand and support the government’s efforts to reduce poverty by increasing the capacity of 
connections to local distribution networks.  The installation of a second transformer at these 
substations should also improve system reliability. The expanded substation capacities will 
connect about 5,000 households in semi-urban and rural areas to the grid.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Financial and Economic Analysis 
1.  Economic Analysis 
63.  The establishment of the wholesale electricity spot market and transmission upgrading 
components are complementary and both are necessary to ensure that a sufficient trading 
market for power is created. The two components have therefore been evaluated together in the 
economic analysis by comparing with-versus-without project scenarios. Without the Project, the 
present structure of the market and tariffs containing distortion will continue, and this will prevent 
the generation and transmission systems from “signaling” the true economic price of electricity. 
With the Project, a competitive electricity market and adequate transmission networks will be 
established. A competitive generation tariff that is “economic” and significantly determined by 
the interaction of market supply and demand will be introduced, and the predicted lower price of 
electricity will generate more power consumption by end users. 
 
64.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of the Project has been calculated for a 
period of 20 years, including construction and operation periods, and is estimated at 24.1% 
(Appendix 12). The EIRR calculation has been subjected to sensitivity analysis to test the effect 
of possible unfavorable changes in key variables. The sensitivity analysis indicates that it would 
require an increase in costs of 73.4% or a decrease in benefits of 42.3% to reach the cutoff 
EIRR of 12%.

16 
2.  Financial Analysis 
65.  A financial analysis was undertaken using 2002 constant prices (Appendix 13). The 
financial analysis for Part A was based on the assumption that the WESM will be operated by 
the IMO, which will be an autonomous and independent entity. On the other hand, the financial 
benefits for Part B were measured as the result of multiplying the incremental electricity sales 
realized through upgrading the transmission lines and expanding of the substation capacities by 
2002 unbundled transmission tariffs. The integrated financial internal rate of return (FIRR) for 
the Project was also computed, simply by summing the costs and the benefits for Parts A and B. 
The results of the analysis are summarized below.  
 
66.  Part A: MMS for WESM.  The income source for the WESM will be the market operation 
fees, which will be approved by ERC and collected from the market participants. The market 
operation fees have been estimated by TRANSCO to be P0.0132/kWh in 2005 and the traded 
electricity volumes are estimated to increase gradually from 43,468 gigawatt-hour (GWh) in 
2005 to 66,210 GWh in 2010.12 It is assumed that about 76% of the nationwide electricity 
volumes will be traded through the WESM because WESM will initially be available for Luzon 
Island. Based on these assumptions, the estimated FIRR for the WESM (part A) is 10.9%, 
compared with a weighted average cost of capital (WACC) of 5.3%.  
 
67.  Part B: Transmission Reinforcement.  Upgrading the Luzon transmission system will 
enable electricity from the power plants in Luzon to be transmitted to the main load centers, 
including Metro Manila, and expanding the Mindanao substations will reinforce the substations 
to meet increased system demand. For Part B, the FIRR was computed based on a 2002 
transmission tariff of P0.3220/kWh for Luzon with projected incremental electricity transmitted 
through  the  upgraded  transmission  lines,  and  a  subtransmission  tariff  of  P0.1476/kWh  for 
Mindanao, with projected incremental electricity transformed through the expanded substations. 
The main project costs for Part B are equipment, civil works, resettlement, and incremental 
O&M costs. Based on the assumptions, the FIRR for part B is estimated to be 16.9%, compared 
with a WACC of 5.3%.  
 
68.  The Project (Parts A and B).  The FIRR of the Project was computed by summing up 
the cash flows for costs and revenues of parts A and B. Based on the above assumptions, the 
FIRR for the Project is estimated to be 14.9%, compared with a WACC of 5.3%. The financial 
net present value, discounted at WACC, is about P 3.9 billion. 
 
B.  Poverty Reduction 
69.  Electricity is an input to most economic processes, and thus is an important ingredient of 
the economic development that is essential for poverty reduction. The Project will help provide a 
reliable  electricity  supply  to  satisfy  the  forecast  electricity  demand,  including  the  demand 
created by accelerated rural electrification initiatives. Although the impact on poverty reduction 
of the Project has not been quantified, the lower power tariff and application of a lifeline rate13 
will benefit poor consumers. Upgrading the Luzon transmission system and expanding the 
Mindanao substations will help meet the additional power demand in their service areas and 
facilitate rural electrification, which will benefit the poor directly and indirectly. With access to 
electricity, the rural poor will enjoy better education, entertainment, communication, health,

70.  A distribution analysis of Project’s net benefits was undertaken, based on the results of 
the Project economic and financial analyses. The Project effects were distributed among the 
stakeholders that gain or lose including TRANSCO, consumers of the project electricity, the 
Government, and labor involved in the Project. The analysis indicates that as a result of the 
Project, while there is an outflow from the Government investing in the Project, TRANSCO, 
consumers and labor all gain economic benefits from the Project. The analysis concludes that a 
substantial portion of the project benefits will go directly to the consumers including low-income 
households and the Project will achieve its primary objective of pro-poor economic growth. 
 
71.  The  Project  aims  to  help  eliminate  cross-subsidies  and  move  prices  toward  cost-
reflective rates by introducing competition into the subsector. As in any removal of subsidies, 
there is scope for potential welfare losses, and poor households are generally more vulnerable 
under such circumstances than the non-poor. Mitigating mechanisms are designed to leverage 
future gains and reduce the near-term burdens of adjustment. One of the measures is ERC’s 
setting of lifeline rates for marginalized end users. The lifeline pricing scheme, as an income 
redistribution measure, is to be reconciled with the system of minimum billing to cover the fixed 
costs of providing electricity services. The lifeline tariff policy is also to be supplemented by 
programs to improve and make less costly the access of poor households, especially rural poor, 
to electricity supply.  
 
C.  Environmental and Social Issues 
1.  Environmental Aspects 
72.  The equipment procured under Part A of the Project will be installed inside TRANSCO’s 
compound in Diliman, Quezon City. Therefore, Part A will not have adverse environmental 
impacts. Transmission components under Part B are classified environment category B. The 
Luzon  transmission  upgrading  will  use  the  ROW  of  existing  transmission  lines  owned  by 
TRANSCO. As such, the Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) does not 
require an initial environmental examination (IEE) and issued a certificate of non-coverage to 
this effect on 16 June 1999. Nevertheless, TRANSCO prepared an IEE for this component to 
meet ADB’s environmental requirements. The Mindanao substation expansion will be within the 
boundaries  of  existing  TRANSCO  substations  and  DENR  approved  a  certificate  of  non-
coverage for this component on 31 January 2000. A summary IEE is attached as Appendix 15. 
 
73.  TRANSCO has agreed that the Project will be designed, implemented, operated, and 
maintained in accordance with (i) the national environmental laws, regulations, and standards, 
(ii)  all  applicable  provincial  and  local  regulations  and  standards  concerning  environmental 
protection, land use, and safety, (iii) ADB’s Environmental Guidelines for Selected Industrial and 
Power  Development  Projects,  and  (iv)  safety,  health,  and  environmental  standards  of  the 
Government. During implementation, TRANSCO will submit biannual progress reports on the 
implementation of the mitigating measures described in the summary IEE, and in compliance 
with safety, health, and environmental standards of the Government. After project completion, 
TRANSCO  will  submit  to  ADB  relevant  documentation  to  demonstrate  that  the  Project  is 
operated and maintained in conformity with the applicable safety, health, and environmental 
standards.

  2.  Social Aspects 
   
74.  Although  the  upgraded  Luzon  transmission  lines  will  use  the  existing  ROW,  the 
upgrading work involves land acquisition and resettlement action for new transmission tower 
foundation  footing  sites  and  clearance  of  structures  built  within  the  ROW.  The  Luzon 
transmission upgrading will involve constructing 303 towers, causing land impacts that are 
widespread but individually of very small magnitude. Permanent land impacts are 6.8 hectares 
(ha) of farmland and temporary losses are 413.8 ha. Of these, 213.0 ha are occupied by rice, 
110.7 ha by sugar cane, 66.0 by corn, and 24.1 by trees. In addition, 299 houses and 92 minor 
structures  will  be  demolished.  Construction  of  the  transmission  lines  will  affect  1,535 
landowners. Permanent land impacts will affect 2,391 families (11,955 people) of which 187 
families (935 people) are tenants. Temporary land impacts will affect 1,334 families (5,830 
people) of which 168 (840 people) are tenants. House loss/relocation will affect 321 families 
(1,605  people);  loss  of  minor  structures  will  affect  46  families  (230  people),  and  loss  of 
crops/trees will affect 1,535 families (7675 people). About 70 small businesses will also be 
affected. 
 
75.  TRANSCO has prepared a resettlement plan for upgrading the Luzon transmission lines 
in order to facilitate the payment of relocation and compensation. The plan took account of 
feedback received from the affected communities and the results of socioeconomic surveys. 
ADB  conducted  field  inspections,  and  made  appropriate  recommendations  to  TRANSCO 
concerning implementation of the plan. The resettlement plan and the process used to formulate 
it have been reviewed and comply with ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement. A summary 
of the resettlement plan is included in Appendix 16.  
 
76.  TRANSCO has overall responsibility for the land acquisition and resettlement program 
including planning, implementation, and financial tasks. Preparation, survey, and monitoring 
tasks will reside with the TRANSCO’s social engineering and ROW management department. 
Project  offices,  in  collaboration  with  local  government  units,  will  be  responsible  for  actual 
implementation work in the field including consultation with stakeholders, final identification of 
affected families, and delivery of compensation. TRANSCO will establish a monthly reporting 
system involving project offices’ staff, local government units and affected families. External 
monitoring  will  be  assigned  to  an  independent  agency  tasked  with  the  verifying  internal 
monitoring results and evaluating the resettlement program at the end of the Project. 
 
D.  Project Risks 
77.  Several risks are associated with the proposed Project, and measures are included to 
minimize them. The Project's main risks relate to the pace of the PSRP agreed with ADB. 
Therefore, continued policy dialogue and close monitoring will be necessary to ensure adequate 
progress in this regard. 
 
78.  Although competitive electricity markets have been successfully implemented in several 
countries,  the  California  electricity  crisis  has  brought  to  light  the  importance  of  carefully 
designing electricity markets. The design of the WESM in the Philippines has taken into account 
these lessons. For example, with most of the energy demand contracted, the net quantity 
bought and sold on the spot market will only be around 10% initially. The market for this 
“marginal” demand should be quite competitive since there will be more supply than demand. 
The market will, however, send out the correct economic signals for trading energy, supplying 
reserves,  building  new  generating  capacity  or  retiring  old  capacity,  locating  new  load  or

19 
withdrawing  load,  and  reducing  transmission  congestion.  By  retaining  these  economic 
incentives the system should move toward a more efficient and economic industry, as a whole, 
without dramatic short-term effects. 
 
79.  The opening and successful implementation of the WESM will be an important feature of 
the  power  industry  reform,  under  which  generation,  transmission,  distribution,  and  supply 
activities will be separated into independent businesses. It is important that the Government 
maintain its commitment to the reforms. ERC will need to monitor and, if necessary prevent 
possible anticompetitive behavior of distribution utilities on the one hand and newly formed 
generating companies on the other. These risks have been recognized, and the Government 
has realized the importance of market competition to the electricity tariff regime. Adequate 
provisions to mitigate the risks have been included in the EPIRA and its implementing rules and 
regulations.14 ADB has also assisted the Government to define competition policy and strategies 
in the energy sector that will help to further mitigate the risks.15 
 
80.  Advanced  consultant  recruitment  is  being  undertaken  to  minimize  front-end  project 
delays. The international consultants will assist TRANSCO supervise the procurement and 
installation  of  the  complex  information  technology  equipment  for  the  WESM.    Market 
participants are concerned that the selection of IMO be transparent and that the IMO be truly 
independent in operating the WESM. The piggy-backed TA is expected to mitigate the risks of 
market startup by providing independent expert advice to the Government, and by developing 
an implementation plan for the establishment of IMO. 
 
81.  The technical risks associated with the proposed transmission development component 
are considered manageable. Overhead transmission line design and construction are based on 
conventional technology, and power substation expansion will be designed and constructed with 
well-proven technologies.

THE WHOLESALE ELECTRICITY SPOT MARKET 
 
1.  In  the  wholesale  electricity  spot  market  (WESM),  distribution  utilities  and  electricity 
suppliers will be able to purchase their bulk electricity requirements directly from generators or  
buy it on the spot market.  However, in order to encourage participation in the WESM, the 
Electric  Power  Industry  Reform  Act  (EPIRA)  provides  that,  for  the  first  5  years  from 
establishment  of  the  market,  no  distribution  utility  can  source  more  than  90%  of  its  total 
electricity requirements from bilateral supply contracts. 
 
2.  The price of electricity sold through the WESM will be set by the electricity demand 
during a particular trading period and the bids by generators to supply electricity into the market.  
Generators  will  be  dispatched  on  the  basis  of  their  supply  bids  and  the  most  expensive 
generator will set the clearing price for that trading period.  As generators will be competing for 
supply on the basis of price, prices can be expected to fall when there is a surplus of generation 
(the current situation in the Philippines).  However, when there is a shortage of generation 
prices will rise to the point where new generators can be expected to enter the market. 
 
3.  Wholesale electricity markets have been established in a number of counties throughout 
the  world,  including  Australia,  England  and  Wales,  New  Zealand,  Scandinavia  and  an 
increasing number of states in the United States.  In Asia, wholesale markets are currently 
being established in the Republic of Korea and Singapore. 
 
4.  The WESM will be managed by an independent market operator (IMO). The IMO will be 
required  to  work  closely  with  the  system  operator,  (National  Transmission  Corporation 
[TRANSCO] or its concessionaire), which will dispatch generation and ensure the integrity of the 
national electricity supply system. More specifically, the IMO will (i) process offers and bids for 
supplying and purchasing electricity, (ii) advise the system operator of the generator dispatch 
schedule that will minimize the overall cost to electricity wholesalers, (iii) process metered data 
collected from the trading nodes, (iv) calculate final wholesale market prices; and (v) facilitate 
the financial settlement for electricity bought and sold through the market. 
 
5.  The market management system (MMS) to be installed under part A of the Project will 
enable the IMO to perform these functions.  It will include interfaces with the system operator, 
generators, and suppliers to provide the technical and financial information needed for the 
market  to  operate  successfully.    When  fully  implemented,  information  transfers  are  to  be 
electronic and automatic. 
 
6.  Under a World-Bank-financed project, TRANSCO is installing the following systems to 
support  the  operation  of  the  WESM:  (i)  a  national  control  center  incorporating  an  energy 
management system that will facilitate the centralized and timely dispatch of generation by the 
system operator, (ii) upgraded metering that will allow electricity generated or consumed at each 
market node to be accurately measured for each trading period, and (iii) a communications 
network that will allow the secure and reliable transmission of generator dispatch instructions 
and metering data to and from the National Control Center. This project is scheduled for 
completion by the end of 2003, on time for the WESM to be fully functional. 
 
7.  The World-Bank-financed systems are necessary for the MMS to be fully functional.  
Since they will not be available for market opening, implementation of the MMS must be 
phased. Initially, the system will have limited functionality and many information transfers will 
have to be done manually.  As the World-Bank-financed systems are completed, they will be

Appendix 4  29 
electronically interfaced to the MMS.  This will permit greater system functionality and the 
increased automation of market operation. 
 
8.  Given  the  complexity  of  the  WESM  design,  a  phased  implementation  has  other 
advantages.  It will allow subsystems to be tested and implemented individually.  This will 
reduce the impact of implementation problems that may arise, and give market participants time 
to implement the systems they require to participate in the new arrangements. 
 
9.  As the current owner of most of the generation that will initially participate in WESM, 
National Power Corporation (NPC) is negotiating transitional supply contracts with distributors.  
These contracts, which must be approved by the Energy Regulatory Commission (ERC) before 
they become effective, will limit the exposure of generators and distributors to large fluctuations 
in the wholesale electricity price during initial market operation. When the transitional supply 
contracts expire, generators and suppliers will be able to bilaterally negotiate supply contracts, 
should they wish to reduce exposure to market price volatility.  Over the longer term, the spot 
market prices in the WESM will be reflected in bilateral contract prices and all wholesale 
electricity will move to an economically efficient price level. 
 
86.  The WESM will be applied initially to Luzon Grid and, when fully implemented, will be 
extended to Visayas and Mindanao.  The MMS will be designed to address multi-grids or multi-
areas, and sized to accommodate data for the whole Philippines. Hence, the Mindanao grid can 
be covered by the WESM whether it is connected or not to the Luzon and Visayas grid. While 
Mindanao remains isolated, competition for electricity supply in Mindanao will be limited to the 
trading participants in Mindanao.

A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The  Power  Sector  Assets  and  Liabilities  Management  Corporation  (PSALM)  is  the 
special purpose vehicle established under the Electric Power Industry Reform Act (EPIRA) to 
implement a major component of the Government's plan to restructure the power industry. It is 
the entity responsible for liquidating the National Power Corporation’s (NPC) liabilities by using 
the sales proceeds, universal charges, and other cash inflows (e.g., net profits of the National 
Transmission Corporation (TRANSCO) and of the Agus and Pulangui hydropower stations). In 
line with this responsibility, PSALM will assume responsibility for all NPC's loan payments and 
other debt repayment obligations, including this loan. PSALM will cease to exist in 25 years and 
at that time all its outstanding liabilities will revert to and be assumed by the Government in 
accordance with the EPIRA. PSALM's cash flow projections up to 2022 are shown in Table 
A7.1.  
 
2.  NPC's historical financial statements are also included in Tables A7.2, A7.3, and A7.4. 
While the figures used were provided by PSALM and NPC, the valuation of the assets and 
liabilities of PSALM (other than debt) is critically dependent on a number of key value drivers. In 
particular (i) the value of NPC's generation assets depends on the effective price of natural gas 
and the regulated price in transition supply contracts, and (ii) the net present value (NPV) of the 
independent power producer (IPP) liabilities is fundamentally dependent on (and varies with) 
long-term  predictions  of  the  competitive  market  price  and  demand  growth.  However  it  is 
considered that NPC is currently not financially viable because its total liabilities account for 
about 90% of its total assets, and its debt service coverage ratio (DSCR) has been below 1.0 
since 1997. Therefore, the privatization of NPC and introduction of a wholesale electricity spot 
market is considered necessary to the development of a sustainable electricity supply in the 
Philippines.  
 
3.  NPC’s privatization plan has been prepared with the assistance of Credit Suisse First 
Boston  and  N  M  Rothschild  &  Sons  (Rothschild).  Both  companies  (the  Advisor)  are 
internationally reputable and experienced in managing divestitures of this nature. Most of the 
figures and estimations provided by PSALM have been estimated and reviewed by the Advisor. 
While  the  valuation  of  the  assets  and  liabilities  of  PSALM  (other  than  debt)  is  critically 
dependent on a number of key value drivers, PSALM provided the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) with its best estimate of (i) privatization proceeds, (ii) the market value of electricity in the 
competitive wholesale market, (iii) operational revenues of Agus and Pulangui hydropower 
stations; and (iv) other relevant information. 
 
4.  As noted above, PSALM will take over all obligations for NPC's loan payments and other 
debt repayments, including those of TRANSCO, NPC’s small power utilities group (SPUG) and 
the National Electrification Administration (NEA). While TRANSCO and NPC (SPUG) are to be 
separated from NPC without debts and incorporated as separate legal entities, PSALM will 
receive the net profits from the operations of TRANSCO, which is a fully owned subsidiary of 
PSALM, as well as the net proceeds from the privatization of TRANSCO. As the remittances 
from TRANSCO constitute a part of the cash inflows for PSALM, the financial projections of

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  General 
1.  The economic analysis has been carried out by comparing a with-versus-without project 
scenario. Without the Project, the present structure of the market and tariffs containing distortion 
would continue and prevents the generation and transmission systems from “signaling” the true 
economic price of electricity to the end users. With the Project, a wholesale electricity spot 
market  (WESM)  and  adequate  transmission  networks  will  be  established.  A  competitive 
generation tariff that is “economic” and significantly determined by the interaction of market 
supply and demand will be introduced, and the predicted lower price of electricity will generate 
more power consumption by end users. 
 
2.  The economic analysis was conducted using domestic market prices. The economic 
price of non-traded goods is equal to their domestic prices and a shadow exchange rate factor 
of 1.2 (based on the standard conversion factor of 0.83) was applied to calculate the economic 
price of traded goods. Due to the local conditions of the labor market, an unskilled labor 
conversion factor of 0.7 in domestic prices was considered. Based on these assumptions, the 
main costs and benefits have been broken down into traded goods, non-traded goods, and 
skilled and unskilled labor; and specific conversion factors were calculated to value all costs and 
benefits in economic terms. 
 
B.  Costs 
3.  The main project costs include civil works, equipment, hardware and software, project 
management,  and  incremental  maintenance  and  operating  costs,  land  acquisition,  and 
resettlement with and without the Project. The economic costs were estimated from financial 
costs including physical contingencies. Price escalation, interest during construction, and taxes 
were excluded. Residual values of the capital costs were calculated at the end of the project life. 
Financial costs were converted into economic costs using specific conversion factors for capital 
costs and maintenance costs. 
 
C.  Benefits 
4.  The main quantifiable economic benefits from the Project are benefits from incremental 
energy consumption, resulting from a decrease in the price of electricity to the consumer. 
 
5.  The entry of competition in the sector is expected to bring electricity prices closer to 
marginal costs and force overall average electricity prices lower. With the price decrease to the 
consumer, more electricity will be consumed in the with-project as compared with the without-
project scenario. These benefits accrue to incremental energy consumption and are valued at 
consumer willingness to pay. The price elasticity is estimated at about -0.3, on which the 
economic  benefits  from  the  incremental  electricity  consumption  are  measured.  Separate 
willingness to pay in Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao is estimated and a nationwide average 
willingness to pay is valued at around P6.09/kWh. 
 
6.  The Project holds other benefits that are not easy to be quantified, which mainly include 
efficiency  improvement  of  power  facilities,  potential  impact  on  cross-subsidies,  as  well  as 
benefits from reinforcement of transmission and substation.

7.  The promotion of wholesale competition, together with freeing of competition in the 
generation sector through a system of marginal cost pricing will fend off the tendency to become 
inefficient,  both  for  production  (generation  side)  and  consumption  (distribution  and  large 
industrial customer side). With the WESM in place, the power facilities will have to compete on 
the basis of least cost. The generation facilities will be forced to minimize their operating costs. 
Otherwise, they run the risk of not being dispatched and being priced out of the market by more 
efficiently run facilities. This will add pressure to the power facilities concerned to minimize their 
operating costs, and at the same time, encourage efficiency programs that will improve their 
respective heat rates thus leading to greater fuel efficiency. 
 
8.  The present cross-subsidies extended by the Government on electricity tariff shield the 
users of the real value of the product and prevent its economic utilization. The power sector 
reform is scheduled to eliminate the cross-subsidies and move prices toward cost-reflective 
rates by introducing competition into the sector. The positive response of the production sectors 
from the expected lowering of industrial and commercial electricity rates due to the elimination 
of cross-subsidies during the transition period and the approach of electricity prices toward 
marginal cost pricing in the longer run is a significant source of welfare gains for households. 
The  indirect  welfare  effects  operate  through  increases  in  household  incomes  arising  from 
greater production activities and the consequent increase in household demand for goods and 
services.

Both  subprojects  aim  to  promote  the  transmission  facilities,  accommodate  future  demand 
increases, and ensure sufficient, reliable, and stable supply of power to consumers in the 
selected areas, to meet the country’s expected economic recovery and the projected increase in 
the economic activities.

A.  General

are undertaken using 2002 constant prices. The financial analysis for Part A, the wholesale 
electricity spot market (WESM), is conducted on the assumption that WESM will be operated by 
the independent market operator (IMO), an autonomous and independent entity, while the 
system operations will be conducted by the National Transmission Corporation (TRANSCO). 
Therefore, the financial benefits for Part A are evaluated as the net cash flows of the IMO. The 
financial benefits for Part B (Luzon transmission upgrading and Mindanao substation expansion) 
are measured by the incremental electricity sales for Part B, which become realized due to 
upgrading the transmission lines and expanding the substation capacities. The financial benefits 
are estimated by multiplying the excess electricity volumes traded over the existing capacities 
by the current transmission tariffs, which are composed of a transmission component for high 
voltage  electricity  transmitted  by  the  upgraded  transmission  lines  and  a  subtransmission 
component  for  low  voltage  electricity  transformed  by  the  expanded  substations.  While  the 
integrated nature of Part B is taken into account, the incremental electricity sales are recognized 
as the financial benefits of Part B by using both the estimated excess loads over the existing 
capacities  of  the  transmission  lines/substations  concerned  and  the  transmission  and 
subtransmission tariffs. Furthermore, the overall project FIRR analysis is also performed. While 
the two parts are distinct in nature and WESM will be operated by the IMO, the overall FIRR is 
computed simply by summing up the costs and the financial benefits for parts A and B.
